conversation.content: [hesitantly] Um, so I heard from the maintenance guy that, [pause], well, that today's your last day here and, [very quietly], I didn't know if I should, uh, bring it up or not.
[bitter] Five years of keeping this place running and they give me, [sigh], two weeks' notice like I'm some temporary hire.
I've been doing the pools here, [frustrated], for what, five years now, and um, you're the only manager who ever, [trailing off], actually cared if things got done right...
You always showed up when you said you would, [very sincerely], even during that heat wave when half the contractors wouldn't answer their phones, [empathetically], and that meant something to me.
[mumbling] Thanks for that.
The new manager starts Monday and she's already talking about, [anxious], bringing in some corporate pool service company. [groan]

[upset] I figured as much when I saw the email about, [long pause], reviewing all vendor contracts, which is just corporate speak for, [slowly], we're going to replace everyone who's been here, [very melancholic], with whoever's cheapest.

It's not just about the money though, they don't understand that, [regretful], relationships matter in this business, that knowing your vendors, [whispering], actually makes everything run smoother. [cough]
Remember when that kid cracked his head on the diving board and we had to, [quickly], drain the whole pool at midnight?
[relieved] You came out with your crew at eleven PM without even asking about overtime, [warmly], just showed up with coffee and got to work, [confidently], and we had it refilled by morning.

[cheerful] That was a crazy night but we pulled it off because we both knew, [laugh], what needed to happen without having to file, [speeding up], seventeen different work orders and insurance claims, [passionately], we just handled it like professionals who trust each other.

[sad] Well, um, the new manager, she's got her MBA and, uh, she keeps talking about, [monotone], optimizing vendor relationships and leveraging competitive bidding, [clearing throat], like we're all just numbers on a spreadsheet, um, instead of people who've been keeping this place running together.
So I guess this is it then, um, after all these years of, [disconnecting], working together every week, uh, solving problems. [gasp softly]

[apologetic] I tried to put in a good word for you but, well, they already have their preferred vendor list and, [shaky voice], apparently five years of perfect service doesn't mean much, um, compared to a corporate discount.
[exhausted] Well, I hope your next job appreciates what they're getting because, um, you're the best property manager I've worked with in, uh, twenty years of doing this.
[stuttering] I-I, um, well thanks.
[whispering loudly] Um, take care, okay?

[very sad] If you ever need a reference or if I land somewhere that needs pool service, [chuckle], I've got your number memorized after all these years, [friendly], so I'll definitely call. [deep pitch]
Yeah, um, that would be... well, good.

[formal] I suppose I should, um, let you finish up here and, well, [pause], get your equipment loaded since this is, [very slowly], officially your last service call for the property, uh, and I need to go clean out my office anyway. [sniffle]
